I'm not a scientist, just a humble linguist, but here - for what it's worth - is my layperson's attempt to explain this apparent wave-particle duality with common sense and logic (plus a tiny bit of grade-school level physics): suppose that the change of state from wave to particle in the presence of the detector had absolutely nothing to do, as seems to be widely supposed, with human consciousness (let's be honest - a pretty far-fetched explanation!) but were due simply to some kind of physical interaction between the detector (when switched on) and the particle. What if the detector, in the process of observing the particle, were ever so slightly slowing it down, i.e. robbing it of energy in essentially the same way that a freezer robs liquid water of energy and turns it into ice? And what if this (albeit, comparatively minute) loss of energy were just sufficient to turn the wave (analogous to the macrocosmic fluid state) into a particle (analogous to the macrocosmic solid state)? Has anyone ever actually conducted an experiment that would definitively rule this explanation out? And if not, given that it's potentially such a ridiculously simple way of accounting for what happens, isn't it about time that someone did??

First, tell us what is the real experiment that is inspiring this video. I suspect it is related to photon, not electron.
The concept of superposition is not mysterious at all with waves. Fourier analysis is well understood and easy to demonstrate with two sinusoidal wave sources.
For two waves with small difference in frequency, you get the sum and difference called "beating" simultaneously. It is not the stupid cat dead or alive thought experiment, it is a cat 33% dead, 33% alive, 10% quasi dead, 10% quasi alive and 13% intermediary states all at the same time.

All these flunky YouTube videos on "double-slit" experiments miss the point of the experiment.

The real experiment is that only one photon is sent to a sheet with two slits. The slits are only big enough to allow for one photon.
When not observed they interfere. Meaning it can't be determined which slit the individual photon went through. The single photon behaves like a wave that interferes with itself.

But when a device is placed to observe the slits, then the photon only goes through one of the slits each time. It was the observation that affected the photon to behave like a particle. While not being observed it behaves like a wave (able to interfere with itself).

Talk about the real double-slit experiment. It takes special equipment to do it, not some laser pointer!

To extend the analogy, in addition to the cats themselves, which are discrete particles, the cats also meow (waves), and the echoes of their meows against the walls guide them where to go (for some reason they are blind and prone to moving randomly). You can't see the cats themselves (because cats are ninjas, see the many videos on youtube about this) but you can measure their meows and determine when they bumped the walls. Sometimes the cat is in just the right position that the echo of its meow misleads it into thinking it can't go there, and the meows are just at the right frequency that there are certain paths the cats will never cross due to the distribution of meow echoes - or meowchoes, as they are scientifically known.

When there are two cats, their meows end up interfering with one another in such a way that the meowcho interference pattern is changed, and the spots where previously a single cat would not end up due to the destructive meowcho interference against the walls gets changed because of how the other cats meow interferes with it.

No strangeness, no "cats appearing in both places at once", no "despite the fact that the cat wasn't there it was also there and prevented the other cat". Note that in the standard interpretation, cats do not have 9 lives, but an infinite number of parallel lives, none of which are needed when we take meowchoes into account.

The problem I have with the double slit experiment and the Schrödinger Equation used to describe it is that it doesn't tell us anything about the physical laws directing the behavior. What we have here is basically an engineering solution and not a physics solution. From an engineering perspective, tacking a probability function to where the electron may be is good enough. In return, we get transistors, cell phones, etc. (The modern world.) However, from a physical laws perspective of physics, it is completely unsatisfactory. What has occurred basically is that the Double Slit experiment has turned the physical world into a game of Plinko where any outcome is theoretically possible.

Hey, I know that pop science loves to present quantum mechanics as 'weird', 'odd', and use things like 'cat being both alive and dead' or 'going through slits" and all that, but it's been nearly 100 years since quantum mechanics became established science; it's no longer supposed to be weird and odd. It is only (and should only be presented as such) as very, very successful way of describing and thinking about certain phenomena. Cats don't display observable wave-like properties through double slits, particles do.  That's sort of it.  I'm not even sure why we still talk about particles in the classical sense - electrons are never "particles" as being like little balls.  They only act like it in certain circumstances (like being absorbed by a screen).  "Particle is in a super position" is more accurately, "The amplitude describing a particle is in a super position".

The whole concept is weird as long as you think of the particles as "real things" as we experience in our everyday life. The crux of the matter (if I remember correctly) is that the "particles" are more aptly described to be a "probability wave", meaning they aren't actually particles until you measure them. What we call particles is just the inference of one wave function with another, leading to a "collapse" of the wave function, i.e. all probabilities that could have been, but are not, cease to be a possibility. It's really friggin' weird to try and understand and incredibly hard to simplify as a concept, because it is entirely abstract and maths. For everyone wondering, yes, that is actually what particle physics looks like; pure maths with very little translation to "real life".

Well, you are adhering to a particular interpretation on quantum mechanics - specially with the both pass "at the same time". And when you say "happens all the time" there is subtelty to explain. There is is no "formal" proof of QM: it is a story we tell about the world that makes stupidly good predictions about it (to decimal places beyond our wildest expectations). But saying "if you imagine this (quantum stuff) , then you can predict this very well" is very different- I think - from saying "this is what it is". Taking a stance on this realism/relativism spiel is both a necessary and inevitable epistemological step. You can take a different one, but I believe one must always acknowledge them when talking about what is.

Even if one day we find a "better" interpretation on QM- which I believe we will - its postulates will remain unchanged and thaught by virtue of its phenomenology. This is very similar to how thermodynamics remained unchanged while QM was sending tidal shock waves through the physics community, precisely due to its virtuous phenomenology.
